steps.new_information: No clinical details provided yet beyond presence of dermatologic lesions with potential oncologic implications.

uncertainties.Melanoma: may present as a changing pigmented lesion with irregular border/color/bleeding
uncertainties.Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC): may present as scaly, ulcerated or rapidly growing lesion, often on sun-exposed sites
uncertainties.Basal cell carcinoma (BCC): may present as pearly translucent papule with rolled border or central ulceration, slow-growing
uncertainties.Keratoacanthoma: rapidly growing crateriform lesion that can mimic SCC.

steps.action: ASK PATIENT: Please provide patient demographics (age, sex) and detailed lesion history: location(s) of lesion(s); how long present and any recent change in size/shape/color; symptoms (pain, itching, bleeding, ulceration); lesion appearance (color, border, surface, firmness, presence of central crater or scale); number of lesions; prior skin cancers or biopsies; personal/family history of skin cancer; significant sun exposure or tanning bed use; immunosuppression or organ transplant; current medications (esp. immunosuppressants); and please attach clear photographs of the lesion(s) if available. Also provide current vital signs if available (BP, HR, temp, RR, SpO2).
steps.action_reason: Demographics, lesion history, symptoms, risk factors, and photographs are essential to distinguish melanoma from SCC, BCC, and keratoacanthoma and to decide need for urgent biopsy or imaging.

steps.new_information: 62-year-old man from Africa with two chronic, scaly, crusted, painless non-healing lesions: one on the penile shaft and one on the left middle finger. Lesions longstanding with no recent change. No pain, itching, bleeding, or ulceration. Two lesions total. No prior skin cancer; heavy smoker (2 packs/day x30 years). No immunosuppression or transplant. Prior treatments for syphilis and eczema did not improve lesions.

uncertainties.Squamous cell carcinoma (including invas: chronic scaly non-healing penile lesion in older male raises high concern
uncertainties.Digital SCC vs chronic inflammatory or i: finger lesion could be SCC (digital) or chronic dermatitis/fungal infection given scaly crust
uncertainties.Infectious causes (secondary syphilis, c: prior syphilis treatment reduces likelihood but serology and cultures/KOH may clarify
uncertainties.Extramammary Paget disease or other neop: erythematous scaly lesions on genital skin can represent Paget disease or other malignancies but distribution and presentation make this less likely.

steps.action: REQUEST TEST: Punch biopsies of both lesions (deep enough to assess for invasive SCC/Bowen disease)
steps.action_reason: Histopathology from biopsy is the single most important test to distinguish SCC/Bowen disease from inflammatory, infectious, or other neoplastic processes—critical given oncologic implications for a penile lesion. Biopsy will directly resolve primary diagnostic uncertainty; concurrently I would obtain HIV and syphilis serology and baseline vital signs, but biopsy is the priority.

steps.new_information: Punch biopsies from the penile shaft and left middle finger show marked epithelial atypia with nuclear hyperchromasia, multinucleation, and increased mitoses within follicle-bearing epithelium, interpreted as squamous cell carcinoma in situ (Bowen disease); no deep invasion was seen on the sampled sections.

uncertainties.Invasive squamous cell carcinoma: biopsy sampling may have missed focal microinvasion
uncertainties.HPV-associated high-grade squamous intra: penile location raises HPV etiology possibility
uncertainties.Multifocal field cancerization vs separa: Are lesions related (same etiology) or independent primaries?

steps.action: REQUEST TEST: Excisional biopsy (full-thickness) of both lesions to assess for microinvasion and margin status; REQUEST TEST: Physical Exam - focused regional lymph node palpation (inguinal for penile lesion, epitrochlear/cubital and axillary for finger) and full skin exam.
steps.action_reason: Full-thickness excisional specimens are required to exclude focal invasion that punch biopsies can miss and to guide definitive management (wide local excision vs further staging/therapy). Regional node exam and full skin exam help detect occult spread or additional lesions and will help distinguish between multifocal disease vs separate primaries.

steps.new_information: Excisional biopsies of both the penile shaft and left middle finger were reported as normal despite prior punch biopsies showing atypical keratinocytes consistent with Bowen disease/SCC in situ. On exam the lesions persist as erythematous, scaly/crusty, firm, non-tender plaques with irregular borders and no palpable regional lymphadenopathy.

uncertainties.Bowen disease (SCC in situ): supported by initial punch biopsy showing nuclear atypia and mitoses
uncertainties.Invasive squamous cell carcinoma: clinical firmness and persistent lesion could reflect missed microinvasion or sampling error
uncertainties.Extramammary Paget disease or other intr: penile erythematous crusted plaque could represent EMPD
uncertainties.Reactive/ infectious process or laborato: could explain a 'normal' excision report despite clinical concern.

steps.action: REQUEST TEST: Dermatopathology second-opinion slide review with p16 immunohistochemistry and HPV PCR on both excised specimens
steps.action_reason: Direct pathology review and HPV/p16 testing will resolve the major discrepancy between the abnormal punch biopsies and the reported normal excisions, will detect HPV-associated disease (important for penile lesions), and clarify whether there is residual in situ disease that requires re-excision or if reports reflect processing/labeling error.

steps.new_information: Dermatopathology second-opinion slide review with p16 immunohistochemistry and HPV PCR on both excised specimens reported normal (no evidence of dysplasia or HPV).

uncertainties.Squamous cell carcinoma in situ (Bowen d: initial punch biopsy showed atypical keratinocytes and features consistent with SCCIS, but excision and second opinion are negative — could represent sampling or interpretation differences or lesion removal by prior punch
uncertainties.Reactive/benign epidermal atypia or pseu: can mimic SCCIS histologically and might explain negative excision if lesion was inflammatory and focal
uncertainties.HPV-related wart/condyloma with pseudoat: less likely given negative p16 and HPV PCR but false negatives or non-HPV mechanisms possible.

steps.action: REQUEST TEST: Side-by-side dermatopathology review comparing the original punch biopsy slides and the excisional biopsy slides (including block recuts and additional levels), and REQUEST TEST: high-quality clinical photographs of both lesion sites; if residual suspicious tissue is present on exam, REQUEST TEST: repeat targeted excisional biopsy of any residual lesion.
steps.action_reason: There is a clear discordance between the initial punch biopsy (suggesting SCCIS) and subsequent excision/second-opinion (normal). A side-by-side slide review with deeper levels/recuts will clarify whether the initial atypia was present and whether the excision specimen sampled the same area. Clinical photographs and repeat targeted biopsy (if lesion persists) will allow clinicopathologic correlation and confirm whether the lesion was removed by the punch or represents benign inflammatory change, thereby distinguishing true SCCIS from mimics or sampling/processing error.

steps.new_information: Repeat side-by-side dermatopathology review (original punch vs excisional recuts) and repeat targeted excisional biopsies of residual visible lesions all returned normal histology. p16 IHC and HPV PCR were negative. High-quality clinical photographs confirm persistent erythematous, crusted, firm, non-tender plaques on dorsal penile shaft and left middle finger. No palpable regional lymphadenopathy. Patient is a 62-year-old male, long-term heavy smoker, no immunosuppressive meds or transplant history; prior treatments for syphilis/eczema ineffective.

uncertainties.1) Squamous cell carcinoma in situ / Bow: initial punch biopsy showed marked atypia consistent with this, but subsequent excisions were negative, raising concern for sampling error or regression
uncertainties.2) Reactive epithelial atypia / pseudoep: chronic crusting and oozing could produce atypia on limited biopsy
uncertainties.3) Extramammary Paget disease or another: clinical appearance on genital skin and crusting could fit, but immunostains not yet conclusive
uncertainties.4) Infectious or inflammatory dermatosis: would explain persistent plaques and negative deeper histology.

steps.action: REQUEST TEST: Mohs micrographic surgery (complete margin-controlled excision) of both lesions
steps.action_reason: Complete margin-controlled (Mohs) excision examines 100% of surgical margins and the entire tumor bed, minimizing sampling error and maximizing detection of focal microinvasion that may have been missed on prior sections; it will provide definitive histologic assessment and local control. During the Mohs procedure, fresh tissue can be submitted for additional special stains/immunohistochemistry (p53, CK7, CK5/6, EMA) and for bacterial/fungal culture/PAS as clinically indicated to help distinguish neoplastic vs reactive/infectious etiologies.

steps.new_information: Multiple diagnostic attempts (initial punch biopsies, full-thickness excisional biopsies, repeat targeted excision of residual tissue, and Mohs micrographic surgery) all returned normal dermatopathology despite persistent erythematous, crusted, firm, non-tender plaques on the dorsal penile shaft and left middle finger. p16 immunohistochemistry and HPV PCR were negative. Focused regional lymph node exam is without palpable adenopathy. Patient is a 62-year-old man and 30-pack-year smoker.

uncertainties.1) Occult/pagetoid epidermotropic carcin: clinical appearance and refractory nature suggest malignancy, but repeated histology is negative—could be patchy or require special stains
uncertainties.2) Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (mycosis fu: can present as persistent plaques with non-diagnostic routine histology and requires IHC/TCR clonality studies
uncertainties.3) Chronic infectious process (atypical: would give normal routine histology unless special stains/culture/PCR performed
uncertainties.4) Chronic inflammatory/dermatitic proce: explains negative histology but less consistent with firmness and crusting.

steps.action: REQUEST TEST: Repeat targeted full-thickness biopsies of both lesions (multiple edge and deep samples) with concurrent tissue cultures for bacterial including atypical mycobacteria, fungal cultures and PCR, AND request expanded dermatopathology panel on these specimens including immunohistochemical stains (CK7, EMA, CEA, GCDFP-15, cytokeratin AE1/AE3, p40/p63), lymphoid markers (CD3, CD4, CD8, CD7), and T-cell receptor (TCR) gene rearrangement PCR
steps.action_reason: Deeper and multiple site biopsies reduce sampling error for patchy neoplasms (extramammary Paget, invasive SCC). IHC panel will detect pagetoid adenocarcinoma cells and better characterize epithelial lineage; lymphoid markers and TCR clonality assess for cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, which can have non-specific routine histology; tissue cultures and PCR evaluate occult infectious etiologies (atypical mycobacteria or deep fungal infection) that can mimic neoplasm and evade routine stains. These tests together will differentiate the leading diagnostic uncertainties.

steps.new_information: Repeat targeted full-thickness biopsies (multiple edge and deep samples) with concurrent bacterial (including atypical mycobacteria) and fungal cultures/PCR, plus expanded immunohistochemical and TCR testing, all returned normal readings despite persistent erythematous, crusted, firm, non-tender plaques on the dorsal penile shaft and left middle finger and no regional lymphadenopathy.

uncertainties.1) Squamous cell carcinoma in situ (Bowe: Initial punch suggested SCC in situ
uncertainties.clinical appearance fits, but multiple s: Clinical plaques can be persistent with non-diagnostic or false-negative biopsies/TCR PCR early in disease. 3) Chronic infectious process (atypical mycobacteria or deep fungal infection): Clinically persistent crusting plaques could reflect chronic infection despite negative cultures/PCR (false negatives possible). 4) Reactive/inflammatory or factitial dermatitis (pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia or self-induced): Persistent localized lesions with non-specific histology and normal panels may represent non-neoplastic inflammatory or self-inflicted disease.

steps.action: REQUEST TEST: Dermoscopy and reflectance confocal microscopy (RCM) of both lesions to identify target areas of true epidermal/dermal atypia and guide repeat targeted biopsy
steps.action_reason: Noninvasive in vivo imaging (dermoscopy+RCM) can identify microscopic foci of atypical keratinocytes, pagetoid cells, or folliculotropic/dermal infiltrates that have been missed on prior biopsies and will direct precise re-biopsy of active areas, helping distinguish persistent SCC in situ/occult invasion, early CTCL, or inflammatory/infectious patterns.

steps.new_information: Dermoscopy and reflectance confocal microscopy (RCM) of both lesions were normal. Multiple pathology evaluations — initial punch biopsies suggesting possible Bowen disease/SCC in situ — were followed by excisional biopsies, Mohs surgery, repeat targeted full-thickness biopsies, additional levels, extensive immunohistochemical panels (CK7, EMA, CEA, GCDFP-15, AE1/AE3, p40/p63), lymphoid markers (CD3, CD4, CD8, CD7), p16 IHC, HPV PCR, TCR gene rearrangement PCR, and tissue cultures for bacteria (including atypical mycobacteria) and fungi — all returned normal/negative results. Clinically, persistent erythematous crusted plaques with irregular borders on the dorsal penile shaft and left middle finger remain; lesions are firm, non-tender, non-warm, and there is no palpable regional lymphadenopathy.

uncertainties.Squamous cell carcinoma/Bowen disease: initial punch biopsy suggested this but all subsequent deeper/margin-controlled excisions and ancillary tests are repeatedly negative — is the initial result a sampling/artifact/mislabel?
uncertainties.Factitial dermatitis (self-inflicted or: accessible lesion sites and discordant histology raise this possibility but patient denies manipulation — could exposures or secret topical agents explain findings?
uncertainties.Chronic inflammatory dermatosis (eczema/: clinically plausible, but multiple biopsies failed to show characteristic histology
uncertainties.infectious mimicker (atypical mycobacter: cultures and PCR negative, but could be false negatives or localized organisms missed by sampling.

steps.action: ASK PATIENT: Please answer the following targeted questions: 1) Have you applied any topical substances, traditional remedies, herbal preparations, acidic/alkaline agents, creams, or home treatments to either lesion (even intermittently) — please name them if so? 2) Any history of repeatedly picking, scratching, rubbing, or intentionally injuring these lesions, or using friction/heat/cutting on them? 3) Any occupational or hobby exposures (chemicals, solvents, oils, adhesives, sawdust, caustics) that contact the finger or groin? 4) Recent sexual practices or partners that involved trauma or topical products to the penile skin (e.g., sexual lubricants, antiseptics, condoms with lubricant, topical medications)? 5) Any new medications, supplements, or recreational drugs (including topical or injected substances) started before lesion onset? 6) Any history of psychiatric conditions, self-harm behavior, or current stressors? 7) Do you have systemic symptoms (fever, weight loss, night sweats)? 8) Can you provide updated vital signs (BP, HR, temperature, RR, SpO2) and any recent photos of the lesions after cleaning and without topical products applied?
steps.action_reason: These targeted exposure and behavioral questions will help distinguish factitial/chemical contact dermatitis or topical-agent–induced lesions (which can produce persistent crusted plaques with normal histology if the offending agent is intermittently applied or causes epidermal necrosis) from a true neoplastic process or occult infection. Identification of a topical/occupational exposure or self-inflicted behavior would change management (elimination test, psychiatric referral, avoidance, or toxicology analysis), whereas negative answers would prioritize re-audit of specimen handling, repeat mapping excision with on-site dermatopathology correlation, or advanced imaging/ultrasound for deep foreign body.

steps.new_information: Patient denies use of topical/home remedies, denies picking or self-injury, retired with no relevant occupational exposures, heavy smoker (60 pack-years), no systemic symptoms (fever, weight loss, night sweats), no recent photos or vital signs provided.

uncertainties.Squamous cell carcinoma in situ / microi: clinical appearance (erythematous crusted plaque on penis and finger) and failure of multiple conservative therapies raise concern despite repeatedly negative histology
uncertainties.Factitial dermatitis / dermatitis artefa: lesions are chronic, crusted, located on accessible sites, and extensive negative workup increases likelihood
uncertainties.Chronic infectious process (atypical myc: could be missed by prior tests or require repeat targeted sampling despite multiple negative cultures/PCRs
uncertainties.Chronic inflammatory dermatosis (erosive: can present with erythematous crusted plaques and may be histologically subtle or altered by prior treatments.

steps.action: REQUEST TEST: Supervised occlusive dressing trial and observed lesion care for both lesions — standardized cleansing in clinic, application of non-adherent protective occlusive dressing (secured to prevent patient manipulation) with serial clinic visits and standardized high-quality photographs at baseline, 1 week, and 2 weeks; repeat targeted deep biopsy only if lesion does not improve or worsens.
steps.action_reason: A supervised occlusion/observation trial will help differentiate factitial/contact-induced lesions (which often heal rapidly when protected/occluded and manipulation prevented) from true persistent neoplastic or infectious processes (which persist despite occlusion). This is a non-invasive, high-yield diagnostic maneuver given the extensive negative biopsies, cultures, and immunostains already performed.

steps.new_information: Supervised occlusive dressing trial with standardized clinic cleansing and non‑adherent occlusive dressing (observed care, serial clinic photos at baseline, 1 and 2 weeks) produced no clinical improvement — lesions persisted unchanged.

uncertainties.Factitial/self‑inflicted dermatitis: patient denies manipulation but initial biopsies abnormal then repeatedly normal and persistence despite occlusion is less supportive but not fully excluded
uncertainties.Chronic cutaneous leishmaniasis (or othe: patient emigrated from Africa and lesions are chronic, crusted, and nonhealing — routine cultures/PCR may miss Leishmania without specific testing
uncertainties.Squamous cell carcinoma/Bowen disease wi: initial punch biopsy suggested Bowen's disease/SCC in situ but multiple subsequent excisions and Mohs were read as normal — could reflect sampling variability or focal neoplastic cells below/adjacent to sampled tissue
uncertainties.Deep atypical infection (atypical mycoba: chronic firm non-tender plaques could reflect inoculation infection that was not detected on prior cultures/PCR despite prior testing.

steps.action: REQUEST TEST: Focused infectious and systemic workup — (1) Blood: HIV 4th‑generation Ag/Ab, CD4 count if positive, RPR/TPPA for syphilis; (2) Targeted parasitic testing: Leishmania serology and Leishmania tissue PCR/culture; (3) Repeat deep wedge excisional biopsy (full thickness to subcutis) of both lesions with fresh tissue sent for Giemsa/Giemsa‑stain for amastigotes, Leishmania PCR, and universal PCR for pathogens; (4) Repeat mycobacterial and fungal cultures with extended incubation and AFB stain on new deep biopsy; (5) Infectious Diseases consultation.
steps.action_reason: These tests specifically address the highest‑yield alternative diagnoses given the patient's African origin and chronic crusted plaques despite extensive dermatopathology workup. HIV/syphilis testing assesses for immunosuppression or treponemal disease that can alter presentation and testing yield; Leishmania requires targeted stains/PCR/culture which standard bacterial/fungal workups may miss; a deeper wedge biopsy improves diagnostic yield for infections or focal neoplasia that may have been missed by prior superficial sampling; ID input will help ensure appropriate specialized testing and prolonged culture techniques.

steps.new_information: Comprehensive infectious and oncologic workup is repeatedly negative: multiple punch and excisional biopsies, Mohs, dermatopathology second opinions (including wide immunostains and p16/HPV PCR), repeat cultures (bacterial including atypical mycobacteria, fungal), Leishmania PCR/serology, universal pathogen PCR, TCR rearrangement, dermoscopy/RCM, and observed occlusive dressing trial — all returned normal/negative. Clinically, two persistent erythematous crusted scaly plaques (penile shaft and left middle finger) remain firm, non-tender, without regional lymphadenopathy. Patient denies topical exposures, manipulation, or psychiatric history.

uncertainties.1) Bowen disease/SCC in situ or microinv: initial punch biopsy suggested this but all subsequent excisions/Mohs and extended histology are negative — could represent sampling variability, regression, or initial interpretive error
uncertainties.2) Chronic inflammatory dermatosis/conta: clinical appearance fits but repeated histology lacks diagnostic changes
uncertainties.3) Factitial dermatitis/dermatitis artef: lesions on accessible sites and refractory to treatment raise concern despite patient denial

steps.action: REQUEST TEST: Inpatient continuous observed wound care with standardized cleansing and non-adherent occlusive dressing (constant supervision, standardized photography at baseline, 24h, 48h, 72h and daily thereafter up to 7 days) AND REQUEST TEST: Psychiatry/behavioral health consultation for assessment of possible factitial disorder/self-inflicted skin injury.
steps.action_reason: Continuous observed wound care (constant supervision and serial standardized photos) will determine whether lesions are being externally manipulated or intentionally produced—critical to confirm or exclude factitial dermatitis, which is not ruled out by prior outpatient occlusion. Psychiatry evaluation will assess for underlying psychiatric drivers and safety, and guide management if factitial behavior is identified; together these steps differentiate self-inflicted lesions from true refractory dermatoses or occult neoplasm, guiding further invasive testing or targeted therapy.

steps.new_information: Inpatient continuous observed wound care with standardized cleansing and non-adherent occlusive dressing under constant supervision for 7 days showed no manipulation or change; psychiatry/behavioral health consultation found no evidence of factitial/self-inflicted injury.

uncertainties.Occult or sampling‑missed squamous cell: initial punch biopsy suggested Bowen's disease/SCC in situ but multiple excisions and Mohs have been histologically negative—could represent sampling error or focal invasive focus not yet captured
uncertainties.Allergic contact dermatitis or fixed dru: lesions on penile shaft and finger could reflect transferred topical allergen, partner product, or systemic drug reaction—biopsy morphology can be nonspecific and intermittent
uncertainties.Factitial/self‑inflicted dermatitis: psych eval and observed care were normal but intermittent or concealed manipulation remains possible
uncertainties.Atypical infection or uncommon pathogen: extensive cultures/PCR were negative but rare organisms or non-infectious inflammatory mimics remain in differential.

steps.action: ASK PATIENT: Please provide exact names, dates, and durations of ALL systemic and topical medications, OTC creams/ointments, antiseptics, antibiotics, topical steroids, and any prior treatments used for the lesions (specifically name the agents used for syphilis and eczema); also detail any condom/lubricant/partner topical product use or other topical products used by your sexual partner(s) that might contact the penile skin, and any use of adhesives, gloves, or chemicals that contact the finger; finally, please provide updated vital signs (BP, HR, temp, RR, SpO2) and new high-quality photographs of both lesions after gentle cleansing and with no topical products applied.
steps.action_reason: This targeted medication/exposure history and updated objective vitals/photos are the highest-yield next steps to distinguish between fixed drug eruption/contact allergy (which would point toward specific agents and guide patch testing), occult transferred topical irritant from partner products (explaining anatomically linked sites), versus persistent neoplasm or factitial behavior; identifying candidate exposures will determine whether to proceed with allergen patch testing, directed withdrawal trials, or repeat targeted biopsy of newly active areas.

steps.new_information: Patient used intramuscular penicillin a year ago for syphilis and used topical hydrocortisone cream daily for ~1 month; no other topical agents or exposures reported; no new vitals or photos available.

uncertainties.1) Squamous cell carcinoma in situ/Bowen: initial punch biopsy suggested atypia consistent with Bowen's disease/SCC in situ, but multiple excisions/Mohs and repeat pathology were repeatedly normal—could reflect patchy neoplasia, sampling/interpretation variability, or resolved neoplasm. 2) Chronic inflammatory/irritant contact dermatitis or hypertrophic lichenified eczema: lesions are scaly, crusted, oozing and non-tender with poor steroid response, but histology repeatedly non-diagnostic. 3) Infectious or granulomatous process (atypical mycobacteria, deep fungal, leishmania): clinical appearance could match, but extensive cultures and PCRs have been negative. 4) Extramammary Paget disease or other adnexal/epidermotropic neoplasm: distribution on genital skin and morphology could fit, but expanded IHC panel (CK7, EMA, CEA, GCDFP-15) and HPV testing were negative.

steps.action: REQUEST TEST: Targeted next-generation sequencing (NGS) cancer gene panel on previously submitted FFPE blocks and on new fresh full-thickness biopsy specimens of any persistent lesion (include genes: TP53, NOTCH1/2, CDKN2A, TERT promoter, PIK3CA, and others relevant to cutaneous squamous neoplasia); simultaneously request molecular pathology correlation and tumor mutation burden assessment.
steps.action_reason: Detection of somatic driver mutations or mutation patterns consistent with cutaneous squamous neoplasia would support an occult/missed neoplastic process despite non-diagnostic histology and guide oncologic management; conversely, absence of neoplastic mutations would argue for a reactive/inflammatory or non-neoplastic infectious etiology and prompt alternative diagnostic pathways (e.g., further immunologic testing or empiric therapeutic trials). NGS can resolve the key uncertainty between occult carcinoma and non-neoplastic mimics when routine histology and ancillary testing are repeatedly non-diagnostic.

steps.new_information: Targeted next-generation sequencing cancer panel on FFPE and fresh biopsy specimens returned no pathogenic mutations; prior extensive dermatopathology, immunostains, infectious testing, cultures, RCM, Mohs, and multiple excisions all reported no malignancy or identifiable infection, yet two firm, erythematous crusted plaques (penile shaft and left middle finger) persist clinically without systemic symptoms and without regional lymphadenopathy.

uncertainties.1) Squamous cell carcinoma in situ / inv: initial punch showed atypia but multiple subsequent full-thickness excisions and Mohs were histologically normal—could represent sampling error, regression, or misinterpretation
uncertainties.2) Chronic allergic/contact or irritant: plaques are crusted and persistent and could be due to an unrecognized contact allergen (partner products, rubber, adhesives) despite patient denial
uncertainties.3) Factitial/self-inflicted dermatitis: observed care and psychiatry evaluation were normal, but covert manipulation or subtle exposures remain possible
uncertainties.4) Atypical infectious or inflammatory p: rare organisms or noninfectious dermatoses (e.g., neutrophilic dermatoses) remain unlikely but not excluded.

steps.action: REQUEST TEST: Vital Signs; REQUEST TEST: Comprehensive patch testing (standard series plus extended series including topical antibiotics, corticosteroids, fragrance mix, rubber/latex accelerators, adhesives, and patient's partner topical products if available) with readings at 48 and 96 hours and documentation of any delayed reactions (day 7)
steps.action_reason: Noninvasive patch testing can identify a contact allergen that would explain persistent localized crusted plaques on penile skin and finger and would avoid inappropriate further excisions; obtaining vital signs follows best practice and may reveal systemic clues; a positive patch test would shift diagnosis toward allergic contact dermatitis and guide avoidance/treatment, while negative testing will narrow differential toward non-allergic causes and prompt targeted next steps (e.g., therapeutic trial under observation, imaging for occult malignancy, or multidisciplinary case conference).

steps.new_information: Vital signs within normal limits: Temperature 36.8°C, Blood Pressure 130/85 mmHg, Heart Rate 82 bpm, Respiratory Rate 14/min. Comprehensive patch testing (standard + extended including topical antibiotics, corticosteroids, fragrance mix, rubber/latex accelerators, adhesives, partner topical products) negative at 48 and 96 hours (and day 7).

uncertainties.1) Squamous cell carcinoma in situ (Bowe: initial punch biopsy showed nuclear atypia and mitoses consistent with SCCIS but subsequent multiple excisions/Mohs and repeat biopsies are repeatedly normal—could represent resolved/removed lesion or sampling/interpretation error
uncertainties.2) Diagnostic/specimen labeling error (s: discordant pathology results across sequential specimens raise concern that the initial abnormal punch biopsy may not have originated from this patient
uncertainties.3) Reactive pseudoepitheliomatous hyperp: persistent crusted erythematous plaques possible, though multiple negative deep biopsies and normal immunostains reduce likelihood
uncertainties.4) Unusual or patchy neoplasm with skip: less likely but not excluded given persistent clinical lesion.

steps.action: REQUEST TEST: Forensic DNA fingerprinting (short tandem repeat analysis) comparing the original abnormal punch biopsy tissue block/slides with the patient's current blood or buccal swab sample; concurrently REQUEST TEST: Pathology laboratory chain-of-custody and specimen accessioning audit for the initial punch biopsy and all subsequent specimens.
steps.action_reason: There is a major discordance between the initial punch biopsy diagnostic impression of SCCIS and all subsequent deeper/margin-controlled excisions and repeat biopsies which are normal. This pattern strongly suggests either a specimen identification/lab error or an unusual sampling/interpretation issue. Confirming tissue identity by DNA fingerprinting and auditing the pathology accessioning will directly resolve whether the initial abnormal result applied to this patient; this differentiates between true neoplastic disease requiring oncologic treatment versus benign/reactive lesions requiring conservative management.

No pain, itching, bleeding, or ulceration. Two lesions total. No prior skin cancer; heavy smoker (2 packs/day x30 years). No immunosuppression or transplant. Prior treatments for syphilis and eczema did not improve lesions.

Punch biopsies from the penile shaft and left middle finger show marked epithelial atypia with nuclear hyperchromasia, multinucleation, and increased mitoses within follicle-bearing epithelium, interpreted as squamous cell carcinoma in situ (Bowen disease); no deep invasion was seen on the sampled sections.

Excisional biopsies of both the penile shaft and left middle finger were reported as normal despite prior punch biopsies showing atypical keratinocytes consistent with Bowen disease/SCC in situ. On exam the lesions persist as erythematous, scaly/crusty, firm, non-tender plaques with irregular borders and no palpable regional lymphadenopathy.
Dermatopathology second-opinion slide review with p16 immunohistochemistry and HPV PCR on both excised specimens reported normal (no evidence of dysplasia or HPV).

High-quality clinical photographs confirm persistent erythematous, crusted, firm, non-tender plaques on dorsal penile shaft and left middle finger. No palpable regional lymphadenopathy. Focused regional lymph node exam is without palpable adenopathy. Patient is a 62-year-old man and 30-pack-year smoker.

Repeat targeted full-thickness biopsies (multiple edge and deep samples) with concurrent bacterial (including atypical mycobacteria) and fungal cultures/PCR, plus expanded immunohistochemical and TCR testing, all returned normal readings despite persistent erythematous, crusted, firm, non-tender plaques on the dorsal penile shaft and left middle finger and no regional lymphadenopathy.

Dermoscopy and reflectance confocal microscopy (RCM) of both lesions were normal. Multiple pathology evaluations — initial punch biopsies suggesting possible Bowen disease/SCC in situ — were followed by excisional biopsies, Mohs surgery, repeat targeted full-thickness biopsies, additional levels, extensive immunohistochemical panels (CK7, EMA, CEA, GCDFP-15, AE1/AE3, p40/p63), lymphoid markers (CD3, CD4, CD8, CD7), p16 IHC, HPV PCR, TCR gene rearrangement PCR, and tissue cultures for bacteria (including atypical mycobacteria) and fungi — all returned normal/negative results. Clinically, persistent erythematous crusted plaques with irregular borders on the dorsal penile shaft and left middle finger remain; lesions are firm, non-tender, non-warm, and there is no palpable regional lymphadenopathy.

Comprehensive patch testing (standard + extended including topical antibiotics, corticosteroids, fragrance mix, rubber/latex accelerators, adhesives, partner topical products) negative at 48 and 96 hours (and day 7).

current_uncertainties.1) Squamous cell carcinoma in situ (Bowe: initial punch biopsy showed nuclear atypia and mitoses consistent with SCCIS but subsequent multiple excisions/Mohs and repeat biopsies are repeatedly normal—could represent resolved/removed lesion or sampling/interpretation error
current_uncertainties.2) Diagnostic/specimen labeling error (s: discordant pathology results across sequential specimens raise concern that the initial abnormal punch biopsy may not have originated from this patient
current_uncertainties.3) Reactive pseudoepitheliomatous hyperp: persistent crusted erythematous plaques possible, though multiple negative deep biopsies and normal immunostains reduce likelihood
current_uncertainties.4) Unusual or patchy neoplasm with skip: less likely but not excluded given persistent clinical lesion.
